BradleyHarris

Regrettable in Clive's statement, quoted by you, is his use of absolutist terms--"utterly" and the like.
 
 What I think counts as the effective disproof of the YEC position is this...For the YEC position to be true, SO MUCH ELSE would be falsified that the YEC position owes so massive a recasting and reframing of science as to render it incredible. For example, for YEC to be true, substantially all of the major dating methods currently in use must be either or both mistaken or radically misused--not just carbon dating, but potassium-argon and every other one of a couple of dozen other dating systems. Mountains of theory, method, and data must be displaced for YEC to be true--in geology, geophysics, archaeology, palaeontology, botany...the list goes on.
 
 YEC offers limited explanative power--it functions essentially as a reaction to opposed positions. Propoenents of YEC have offered little in the way of good data or good theory to replace the mass of data and theory they are obliged to displace.
 
 Rather than the notion of "disproof" invoked by Clive, I should rather say this...So-called evolutionist positions owe little obligation of counter-evidence to YEC positions. [There are exceptions: Whenever a case such as the 'Paluxy mantracks' comes up, opponents do owe an explanation to counter.] However, YEC, seeking as in effect it does to displace an immense weight of theory, method, and data, owes a massive obligation indeed. YEC has offered but slight evidence, and some embarrassingly wretched rhetoric, toward satisfying its burden. YEC just hasn't carried anything like the explanative weight it needs in order to be convincing.
 
 Personally, the only folk I know who are "convinced" by the "evidence" typically offered by YEC proponents are those ALREADY convinced of the conclusion, for religious reasons, that humans originated on a 6000 year-old earth a week after that earth was born.
 
 I am, by the way, an Evangelical Methodist by religious persuasion. When I hear the 'arguments' offered by many conservative Christian YEC proponents, I feel acutely embarrassed by my religion. When one hears Southern Baptist Convention head honcho Dr. Adrian Rogers, for example, argue for the bankruptcy of evolutionary theory on the ground that no one has ever seen "a cantaloupe turn into a kitten"--an actual quote--one immediately recognizes a dilemma...Either Rogers actually believes that evolutionary theory would call for such a transformation, in which case we're moved to ask why a man so poorly educated in his subject is permitted to address Christian America over the airwaves on this subject...or Rogers knows full well that evolutionary theory in no way would call for such a transformation, in which case his misleading thread of argument is plainly disingenuous, and intellectually dishonest.
 
 As for me, I'm awed by the God whose powers span billions of years, millions of light years, as well as biological processes we've barely begun to investigate, and which produced humankind. I feel no need to squash God into a 6000-year, human-sized box. I wonder not only at the smallness of the average YEC-er's thinking, but at the smallness of his God.

 Not really. Not in the sense that you mean it.
 
So there would be an element of faith to be able to say you have the right interpretation on the evidence.

 No. No faith at all. Science isn't a matter of just interpretation of the evidence. That is only the beginning. A scientist looks at the evidence, formulates an hypothesis, makes a prediction, and then tests the prediction. There actually isn't any claim that the theories are "right," only that they are the best explanations we can devise for the observed data. There is always the possibility that additional data will not agree, and it will have to be explained in the context of the prevailing theory, or the theory will have to be changed or junked.
 
However is it true that the interpretations of the evidence seems to change in time, and if it is true, then what sort of faith is needed to say the current translations are the rite [sic] translations.

 What are you talking about? What is being translated? Are you talking about the Bible and the changing meanings that have been attributed to that? Of course, it is typical of religions to claim absolute and unchanging right. Science doesn't. Some major theories have been so well tested that it is highly unlikely that new data will change them - plate tectonics (the movement of the plates has been measured but the reasons why they move aren't clearly understood), heliocentrism (pretty secure even though we haven't know about Pluto long enough to have seen it actually complete an orbit), special relativity (it has been tested by comparing two identical atomic clocks, one moved at high speed while the other was stationary). There are lots of scientific theories about our world. And none of them is claimed to be "right" beyond any possibility of contradiction. We're still learning and scientific theories are always regarded as tentative. But many of the major theories have been so well tested that it would be ridiculous to question them at every turn. First, present some heretofore unknown piece of evidence that casts doubt on the theory.
 
 Do you doubt that nuclear theory is correct? Unless you have some evidence that has been tested then there won't be many nuclear power plants shutting down because you don't have faith in them.
 
 Really, claiming that science is faith is just an effort to bring science down to the level of religion, i.e., believing without evidence.
